Award.AwardTitle: Scholarships for Academically Talented and Financially Disadvantaged Undergraduate and Graduate Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project is leveraging a long-standing commitment of the university to provide upward social mobility to low-income students. To this end, the project is awarding scholarships to approximately nineteen unique individuals thereby enabling one advanced undergraduate, nine entering freshmen, six students transferring from 2-year schools, and 3 entering graduate students, to complete either a bachelor's or doctor of philosophy degree in chemistry within four (or two for the transfer students) years of matriculating to Duquesne.

Intellectual Merit: The project is augmenting existing, high quality student-support services with a novel mentoring plan that engages undergraduate students, graduate students, and faculty, both in their traditional academic endeavors but also in the development of skills that will lead to valuable STEM workforce personnel. The project is enabling student success in timely completion of degrees through cohort formation that addresses the challenges of course work. The professional development activities are reinforcing essential skills such as time management, prioritization, critical thinking, writing like a scientist, scientific speaking, advanced instrumentation, and leadership.

Broader Impacts: This successful program is documenting how research universities can integrate scholarship support across all levels of their educational enterprise while ensuring financially-challenged students, at any level, are able to pursue a quality higher education degree. The project is also cementing relationships between the university, local groups that aid in recruiting underserved student populations, and the local industry in which many graduates have found and will continue to find satisfying STEM careers that are also beneficial to society.

Institution.Name: Duquesne University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: DUQUESNE UNIVERSITY OF THE HOLY SPIRIT

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have successfully accomplished the major goals in the "Scholarships for Academically Talented and Financially Disadvantaged Undergraduate and Graduate Student" grant (DUE-1259941) at Duquesne University. Our main goals were to (1) recruit and select academically talented students demonstrating financial need, (2) mentor and motivate students to achieve their optimal academic performance leading to degree completion, and (3) create and nurture an inspiring educational and research culture that produces scientific leaders prepared for the best graduate programs and the U.S. workforce in chemistry and biochemistry. Specifically, we (1) generated a diverse applicant pool of academically talented and financially challenged S-STEM students who desired, yet were not on a path to a higher education. We worked with Duquesne University's Admissions and Financial Aid Offices along with our regional partners to produce lists of applicants ranked by financial need and academic performance. This grant supported 27 academically talented and financially disadvantaged students over five years. A total of 12 B.S./B.A. degrees were earned, where nine of these students have continued in Ph.D. degree programs in chemistry or biochemistry and three earned M.S. degrees in physiology, psychology, or mathematics. Five more students continue to pursue B.S. degrees under other forms of financial support at Duquesne University. Five students dropped out of the program due to the anxiety from being too far from home. Five students completed their Ph.D. dissertations. Next, we (2) provided mentorship for optimal academic performance. We created a mentoring structure that featured student cohorts led by faculty and graduate student leaders. Graduate students were trained for effective mentoring skills to impact undergraduate cohorts. Unique to the proposed program, S-STEM undergraduates were mentored, tutored, and guided by S-STEM faculty and graduate students throughout degree completion to maximize retention and enable undergraduate and graduate students to achieve their best academic performance. In the end, over all 27 students, the average GPA was 3.39 +/- 0.67. Finally, we (3) impacted the educational and research culture. We fostered and nurtured an inspiring educational and research culture that prepared students for the best graduate programs and the U.S. workforce. We reinforced essential skills in time management, prioritization, critical thinking, scientific writing and speaking, leadership, advanced instrumentation, and exposed them to leaders from industry, government, and academics.

Intellectual Merit

Specifically, we have created research opportunities with regional impact in exciting and broad scientific themes, to motivate students to make significant advances in chemical research and discovery and achieve their greatest academic potential. Additionally, we have enhanced scholarly production for both our S-STEM faculty and students. Publications build student resumes, advance faculty careers, and increase the chance of students joining the U.S. workforce. We also provided training on advanced instrumentation. Hands-on experience and training of students was delivered by academic and industrial experts on literature searching, theory and computation, nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy, mass spectrometry, surface chemistry, and light spectroscopy. Importantly, we enriched the students' communication skills. A unique effort that trains students how to speak and write "like a chemist" was integrated into the entire research experience based upon an implementation of the scientific method. Students gave oral and written presentations every other week coinciding with the principal steps of the scientific method. 

Broader Impact

We deepened students' awareness of ethical behavior. An ethics workshop was offered to the students to address an ethical issue. The experience concluded with the presentation of a critical assessment of the ethical issue chosen by the group, along with an invited expert keynote speaker at the annual regional ethics symposium. All students had the opportunity of presenting their research on an ethical topic at the final Pittsburgh Regional Ethics Symposium at Duquesne University with more than 100 student abstracts, 16 team oral presentations and a keynote speaker. Finally, we offered career development and networking opportunities, professional development with world-renowned industrial experts and academic faculty through a weekly seminar program, and travel to national ACS meetings. Our efforts and accomplishments feed directly into the intent of the S-STEM program and have had the consequence of enhancing and diversifying the U.S. workforce by adding experts in the fields of chemistry or biochemistry. All of the graduates (12 undergraduates and five graduate students) are currently employed and contributing to the U.S. workforce.
